entry.title: Mexican football league resumes with no spectators amid pandemic

media:group.media:title: Mexican football league resumes with no spectators amid pandemic
media:group.media:description:
Mexico is moving forward with first division football. The opening match of the 2020 Liga MX was played on Friday after being postponed by a day despite warnings over a heightened risk of coronavirus spreading among players.
Al Jazeera's Manuel Rapalo reports from Mexico City.

entry.title: Wuhan on alert again: Flooding poses threat to 11 million people

media:group.media:title: Wuhan on alert again: Flooding poses threat to 11 million people
media:group.media:description:
It has been nearly seven months since the world's first coronavirus infection was reported in the Chinese city of Wuhan. Its 11 million people were forced into a strict lockdown for two months. Many people died of COVID-19. Those who survived the pandemic have been struggling to recover from its effects. And, flooding comes as a new threat for them.
Al Jazeera's Katrina Yu reports from Wuhan, China.

#China #ChinaFloods #Wuhan

entry.title: Coronavirus pandemic: UK to quarantine travellers from Spain

media:group.media:title: Coronavirus pandemic: UK to quarantine travellers from Spain
media:group.media:description:
A rise in COVID-19 infections in Spain drives up fears of a resurgence in Europe. The United Kingdom is reimposing a 14-day quarantine rule on travellers returning from Spain. Infections have tripled there in the past two weeks, with Catalonia emerging as a new hotspot.
Al Jazeera's Sonia Gallego reports.

#Coronavirus #Spain #UKquarantine

entry.title: Portland: Protests against police brutality persist

media:group.media:title: Portland: Protests against police brutality persist
media:group.media:description:
US federal agents sent to Portland by President Donald Trump have again fired tear gas at protesters and made arrests. Demonstrators have rallied every night for eight weeks demanding racial equality and police reforms. Leaders in Oregon state say the agents are only making things worse. Al Jazeera’s Leah Harding reports.

#AlJazeeraEnglish #US #Protests

entry.title: China orders closure of US consulate in Chengdu

media:group.media:title: China orders closure of US consulate in Chengdu
media:group.media:description:
The diplomatic crisis between China and the United States is deepening. Staff at the US consulate in Chengdu, China, are leaving after Beijing ordered its closure. It is in response to the US ordering the closure of China's consulate in Houston, Texas. Al Jazeera’s Katrina Yu reports.

entry.title: Russia politics: Third week of protests in Khabarovsk region

media:group.media:title: Russia politics: Third week of protests in Khabarovsk region
media:group.media:description:
Some of the largest anti-government protests for years in Russia are into their third week. The arrest of the governor of the Khabarovsk region in the far east sparked protesters' anger which shows no sign of subsiding. Al Jazeera’s Katia Lopez-Hodoyan reports.

entry.title: Dakar Youth Olympic Games delayed until 2026

media:group.media:title: Dakar Youth Olympic Games delayed until 2026
media:group.media:description:
The Youth Olympic Games were scheduled to take place in Dakar next year, but they have been moved to 2026 due to the coronavirus pandemic after a mutual agreement between the International Olympic Committee (IOC) and Senegal. The postponement of the first Olympic event to be held in Africa comes as a setback however for many young athletes. Al Jazeera’s Nicolas Haque reports from Dakar.

#AlJazeeraEnglish #Olympic #Dakar

entry.title: Is Zimbabwe cracking down on dissent? | Inside Story

media:group.media:title: Is Zimbabwe cracking down on dissent? | Inside Story
media:group.media:description:
Zimbabwe's President Emmerson Mnangagwa is accused of trying to destroy opposition and silence dissent using COVID-19 as an excuse. The accusations are not new. Political arrests and crackdowns on demonstrations have become common. But the recent arrest of investigative journalist Hopewell Chin'ono has brought back Zimbabwe into the international spotlight. Chin'ono is accused of inciting public violence. He denies that and says journalism is being criminalised. He's published articles alleging corruption in multi-million dollar deals to combat coronavirus that have been awarded to powerful individuals close to the government. What does it tell us about Zimbabwe after Mugabe?
Presenter: Laura Kyle
Guests Bright Matonga, Zanu -PF member and former Deputy Information Minister in the cabinet of President Robert Mugabe. Obert Gutu, former MDC National Spokesperson and Deputy Minister of Justice and Legal Affairs. Piers Pigou, Senior Consultant for Southern Africa for the International Crisis Group, where he also covers Zimbabwe.
- Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/

entry.title: Water shortage fears: Sudan’s fishermen concerned over dam

media:group.media:title: Water shortage fears: Sudan’s fishermen concerned over dam
media:group.media:description:
As the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam nears completion, some communities in Sudan are concerned about the potential effect on their livelihoods. Al Jazeera’s Hiba Morgan travelled to Lake Nubia, which is shared by Egypt and Sudan, to speak to farmers and fisherman about their concerns.

entry.title: UK: Millions miss cancer screening and treatment due to COVID-19

media:group.media:title: UK: Millions miss cancer screening and treatment due to COVID-19
media:group.media:description:
In the United Kingdom, about two million people are waiting for cancer screenings or treatment. Waiting lists have been getting longer as the public health service prioritised COVID-19. Al Jazeera’s Emma Hayward reports.

entry.title: Dozens of journalists resign from Hungary news site in protest

media:group.media:title: Dozens of journalists resign from Hungary news site in protest
media:group.media:description:
Protests were held in Budapest against restrictions on media freedom in Hungary. The demonstrations follow a mass walkout of journalists from the country's most-read website over "government interference". Critics say it is the latest efforts to bring independent media outlets in the country under government control. Al Jazeera's Cara Legg reports.

#AlJazeeraEnglish #Hungary #Pressfreedom

entry.title: US coronavirus: Florida isolation centres used to shield elderly

media:group.media:title: US coronavirus: Florida isolation centres used to shield elderly
media:group.media:description:
Florida is one of the states where infections are surging and now COVID-19 isolation centres are being set up. They are designed to stop the disease from spreading among elderly and vulnerable people. But the strategy is not without risks. Al Jazeera's Andy Gallacher reports from Miami, US.

entry.title: China's Pushback: Beijing questions Western reporting on Xinjiang | The Listening Post (Full)

media:group.media:title: China's Pushback: Beijing questions Western reporting on Xinjiang | The Listening Post (Full)
media:group.media:description:
Despite China's best efforts, journalists are finding innovative ways to tell the story of the mass internment of Uighur Muslims in the Xinjiang province.
Contributors:
Timothy Grose - Assistant Professor of China Studies, Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology Alim Seytoff - Director of Uyghur Service, Radio Free Asia Adrian Zenz - Senior Fellow in China Studies, Victims of Communism Memorial Foundation Sophie Richardson - China Director, Human Rights Watch
On our radar
A journalist in Pakistan is abducted by mysterious armed men and then released. In Zimbabwe, a journalist is arrested. Both men seemingly targeted for criticising people in power. Richard Gizbert speaks to producer Nic Muirhead about both these cases.
Mammy, Jezebel, Sapphire: Stereotyping Black women in media
The stereotyping of Black women in the media and the push for change in an industry where diversity and inclusion have been too long in coming.
Contributors:
Kovie Biakolo - Culture writer and multiculturalism scholar Francesca Sobande - Lecturer of Digital Media Studies, Cardiff University Naeemah Clark - Professor of Cinema and Television Arts, Elon University and Author, Diversity in US Mass Media Babirye Bukilwa - Actor and playwright
- Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/

entry.title: Big Pharma and the cost of developing COVID-19 drugs and vaccines | Counting the Cost

media:group.media:title: Big Pharma and the cost of developing COVID-19 drugs and vaccines | Counting the Cost
media:group.media:description:
The race to develop vaccines and treatments for the coronavirus pandemic is entering a crucial stage with large-scale trials under way.
But with seemingly little oversight on pricing, some experts are concerned that pharmaceutical companies could end up charging way too much for COVID-19 treatments.
And if rich nations corner the market on vaccines, they could also limit accessibility for low-income countries.
Plus, Twitter found itself at the centre of a hack that compromised its high-profile users' accounts. We talk to the CEO of a Silicon Valley company that uses biometrics and artificial intelligence to protect accounts.
- Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/

entry.title: Boeing 737 jets idled during pandemic must be inspected: FAA

media:group.media:title: Boeing 737 jets idled during pandemic must be inspected: FAA
media:group.media:description:
US aviation authorities have ordered emergency inspections for some Boeing aircraft. They are worried about the corrosion in planes that have been sitting idle for months during the pandemic. Al Jazeera's Neave Barker reports.
